photo.description: Photographed at the 2009 International Route 66 Mother Road Festival in Springfield, Illinois on September 25-27, 2009. **************************************************************************************************** You are invited to stay and browse through my stream. Here's a quick index to my little corner of Flickr: Automobile Photographs: This is a very large collection of images whose primary, but not exclusive, focus is on American automotive classics. Images are organized by decade, by manufacturer, and by topics (such as convertibles, station wagons, muscle cars, etc.) Central Illinois (except Springfield): Central Illinois (except Springfield): Photos relating to the middle section of the "Land of Lincoln" (except for the Capital City of Springfield) may be found in this collection. Every city and town I've photographed is contained within its own set, and rural (as in "countryside") photographs are grouped by county. Springfield, Illinois: All of my photographs of Springfield and the Abraham Lincoln Sites are in this collection. For the City of Springfield, there are separate sets for the Capitol Complex, Downtown (including the Old State Capitol), Neighborhoods, Parks, Illinois State Fairgrounds and more. Photographs of Lincoln sites include the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, Lincoln Home National Historic Site, Lincoln Tomb, and so on. Also in the Lincoln "All About Abe" (Set) are a few Lincoln sites not located in Springfield. The Illinois State Fair: My collection of photographs of the Illinois State Fair. The fair offers something for everyone. Grab a corn dog and lemon shake-up, and come take a look! Beyond Central Illinois: Other locales in the United States and Canada including New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Seattle. In addition to my location-based sets, here are links to some "topical" collections and sets I've put together: Barbers & Barber Shops: Traditional barbers and barber shops are on the endangered species list. But there are still plenty to be found if you go looking for them. Almost Everything Else. Check It Out!!!: Included topics range from man's first walk on the moon to small town schools and churches, and from Soft-Coated Wheaten Terriers (our favorite breed) to things that are abandoned, neglected, weathered, or rusty. Thanks for stopping by! - myoldpostcards (Randy von Liski)

photo.description: The Pontiac Grand Ville was the top-line luxury car in the division's full-sized line from 1971 to 1975, displacing the Bonneville which had served as Pontiac's flagship since 1957. For 1975, the Grand Ville became the Grand Ville Brougham and included a bit more standard equipment than in previous years such as power windows and carpeted trunk. This would be the final year for the Grand Ville series, and this full-sized convertible would be the division's final ragtop until 1984. Grand Ville convertibles were scarce in the years from 1971 to 1975 never topping 5000 rag tops per year during the model run. 4,519 convertibles were built for the 1975 model year, and the car sold at a base price of $5,858. Photographed at the 2009 International Route 66 Mother Road Festival in Springfield, Illinois on September 25-27, 2009. **************************************************************************************************** You are invited to stay and browse through my photostream. Here's a quick index to my little corner of Flickr: Automobile Photographs: This is a very large collection of images whose primary, but not exclusive, focus is on American automotive classics. Photographs of Lincoln sites include the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, Lincoln Home National Historic Site, Lincoln Tomb, and so on. Also in the Lincoln "All About Abe" (Set) are a few Lincoln sites not located in Springfield. The Illinois State Fair: My collection of photographs of the Illinois State Fair. photo.description: The Pontiac Grand Ville was the top-line luxury car in the division's full-sized line from 1971 to 1975, displacing the Bonneville which had served as Pontiac's flagship since 1957. For 1975, the Grand Ville became the Grand Ville Brougham and included a bit more standard equipment than in previous years such as power windows and carpeted trunk. This would be the final year for the Grand Ville series, and this full-sized convertible would be the division's final ragtop until 1984. Grand Ville convertibles were scarce in the years from 1971 to 1975 never topping 5000 rag tops per year during the model run. 4,519 convertibles were built for the 1975 model year, and the car sold at a base price of $5,858. photo.description: The Pontiac Grand Ville was the top-line luxury car in the division's full-sized line from 1971 to 1975, displacing the Bonneville which had served as Pontiac's flagship since 1957. For 1975, the Grand Ville became the Grand Ville Brougham and included a bit more standard equipment than in previous years such as power windows and carpeted trunk. This would be the final year for the Grand Ville series, and this full-sized convertible would be the division's final ragtop until 1984. Grand Ville convertibles were scarce in the years from 1971 to 1975 never topping 5000 rag tops per year during the model run. 4,519 convertibles were built for the 1975 model year, and the car sold at a base price of $5,858. Photographed at the 2009 International Route 66 Mother Road Festival in Springfield, Illinois on September 25-27, 2009. **************************************************************************************************** You are invited to stay and browse through my photostream. photo.description: The Pontiac Grand Ville was the top-line luxury car in the division's full-sized line from 1971 to 1975, displacing the Bonneville which had served as Pontiac's flagship since 1957. For 1975, the Grand Ville became the Grand Ville Brougham and included a bit more standard equipment than in previous years such as power windows and carpeted trunk. This would be the final year for the Grand Ville series, and this full-sized convertible would be the division's final ragtop until 1984. Grand Ville convertibles were scarce in the years from 1971 to 1975 never topping 5000 rag tops per year during the model run. 4,519 convertibles were built for the 1975 model year, and the car sold at a base price of $5,858. Photographed at the 2009 International Route 66 Mother Road Festival in Springfield, Illinois on September 25-27, 2009. **************************************************************************************************** You are invited to stay and browse through my photostream. photo.description: Photographed at the 2009 International Route 66 Mother Road Festival in Springfield, Illinois on September 25-27, 2009. **************************************************************************************************** You are invited to stay and browse through my stream. Here's a quick introduction to my little corner of Flickr: Automobile Photographs: This is a very large collection of images whose primary, but not exclusive, focus is on American automotive classics. Images are organized by decade, by manufacturer, and by topics (such as convertibles, station wagons, muscle cars, etc.) Central Illinois (excluding Springfield): Photos relating to the middle section of the "Land of Lincoln" (except for the Capital City of Springfield) may be found in this collection. Every city and town I've photographed is contained within its own set, and rural (as in "countryside") photographs are grouped by county. Springfield, Illinois: All of my photographs of Springfield and the Abraham Lincoln Sites are in this collection. For the City of Springfield, there are separate sets for the Capitol Complex, Downtown (including the Old State Capitol), Neighborhoods, Parks, Illinois State Fairgrounds and more. Photographs of Lincoln sites include the Abraham Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum, Lincoln Home National Historic Site, Lincoln Tomb, and so on. Also in the Lincoln "All About Abe" (Set) are a few Lincoln sites not located in Springfield. The Illinois State Fair: My collection of photographs of the Illinois State Fair. The fair offers something for everyone. Grab a corn dog and lemon shake-up, and come take a look! Beyond Central Illinois: Other locales in the United States and Canada including New York, Chicago, San Francisco and Seattle. In addition to my location-based sets, here are links to some "topical" collections and sets I've put together: Barbers & Barber Shops: Traditional barbers and barber shops are on the endangered species list. But there are still plenty to be found if you go looking for them. Almost Everything Else. Check It Out!!!: Included topics range from man's first walk on the moon to small town schools and churches, and from Soft-Coated Wheaten Terriers (our favorite breed) to things that are abandoned, neglected, weathered, or rusty. Thanks for stopping by! - myoldpostcards (Randy von Liski)

photo.description: The Pontiac Grand Ville was the top-line luxury car in the division's full-sized line from 1971 to 1975, displacing the Bonneville which had served as Pontiac's flagship since 1957. For 1975, the Grand Ville became the Grand Ville Brougham and included a bit more standard equipment than in previous years such as power windows and carpeted trunk. This would be the final year for the Grand Ville series, and this full-sized convertible would be the division's final ragtop until 1984. Grand Ville convertibles were scarce in the years from 1971 to 1975 never topping 5000 rag tops per year during the model run. 4,519 convertibles were built for the 1975 model year, and the car sold at a base price of $5,858. photo.description: The Lincoln Home, part of the Lincoln Home National Historic Site (1846). It was the only house that Abraham Lincoln ever owned. He bought the house shortly after the birth of Robert Todd Lincoln in 1844. He lived here until leaving Springfield for the White House. In 1846, he was elected the U.S. House of Representatives as a Whig and served one term. Also that year, he expanded the house from one story to two. He ran for Seante in 1854, but lost to his rival Stephen A. Douglas. In 1856, he placed second in the contest to be the newly-founded Republican Party's vice presidential candidate. Robert Todd donated the house to the State in 1887 under the condition that it would always be free to the public.

photo.description: The Arnold House at the Lincoln Home National Historic Site (1839). Rev. Francis Springer built a house here in 1841 and held Evangelical Lutheran services. Springer became president of Hillsboro College in 1850. He sold the house to Charles Arnold for $800. Arnold was a political ally of Lincoln and was county sheriff.

photo.description: Mr. Lincoln's Springfield home. He and Mary Todd Lincoln lived here from 1844 until they left for Washington in 1861. Three of the four Lincoln sons were born here, and one (Edward) died here in 1850 at nearly four years of age. When Lincoln won the 1860 Republican Presidential nomination, he received a delegation of party officials in his parlor.

photo.description: The Cook House at the Lincoln Home National Historic Site (c. 1880). Mrs. Sarah Cook, a photographer and widow, rented the property.

photo.description: The Sprigg House at the Lincoln Home National Historic Site (1851). Julia Sprigg, who became a friend of Mary Lincoln, bought the house in 1853. Tad Lincoln played with Sprigg's children. Sprigg's daugter was an occasional caretaker for the young Lincoln children.
photo.tags: nationalhistoricsite illinois 1850s sangamoncounty
photo.title: Sprigg House

photo.description: The Dean House at the Lincoln Home National Historic Site (c. 1855). It was purchased by Mrs. Harriet family only days before her husband Frederick Dean would leave Springfield for the California Gold Rush.
photo.tags: illinois 1850s nationalhistoricsite sangamoncounty
photo.title: Dean House

photo.description: The Lyon House at the Lincoln Home National Historic Site (c. 1855). It was rented to Henson Lyon, who owned a farm two-and-a-half miles east of Springfield. In 1868, it was purchased by Samuel Rosenwald, the father of Julius Rosenwald (part-owner of Sears, Roebuck & Co., founder of the Rosenwald fund, and founder of the Museum of Science & Industry in Chicago).
